title: Trump says he expects Ukraine to sign critical minerals...
body:
Trump: 'They don't have any cards, but they're playing tough' Zelenskiy says he seeks a 'fair result'

*

US proposes UN resolution to mark Russia invasion

(Adds Trump comments paragraphs 1-2, 7-8, Zelenskiy comment paragraph 3, background paragraph 20, U.N. resolution paragraphs 15-16)

By Nandita Bose and Steve Holland

WASHINGTON, Feb 21 (Reuters) -

President Donald Trump

said on Friday he expects Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to sign a minerals agreement with the United States soon as part of efforts to end the Ukraine war.

"We're signing an agreement, hopefully in the next fairly short period of time," Trump told reporters in the Oval Office when asked about a deal for Ukraine's minerals.

Zelenskiy said separately that Ukrainian and U.S. teams were working on a draft agreement. "I am hoping for ... a fair result," he said in a video address on Friday after sharp exchanges between the two leaders.

Trump denounced Zelenskiy as a "dictator" on Wednesday and warned he had to move quickly to secure peace with Russia, which invaded Ukraine nearly three years ago, or risk losing his country.

The sharp change in tone from the United States, Ukraine's most important backer, has alarmed European officials and stoked fears that Kyiv could be forced into a peace deal that favors Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Zelenskiy had said Trump was trapped in a "disinformation bubble", but later toned down his statements and said he was hoping for American pragmatism.

Trump said he believes Putin and Zelenskiy "are going to have to get together, because you know what? We want to stop killing millions of people."

"That's why I want to see a ceasefire. And I want to get the deal done. I think we have a chance to get the deal done. I had to make sure that Russia wanted to do it," he said.

Zelenskiy on Wednesday rejected U.S. demands for $500 billion in mineral wealth from Ukraine to repay Washington for wartime aid, saying the United States had supplied nowhere near that sum so far and offered no specific security guarantees in the agreement.

Ukraine has valuable deposits of strategic minerals that the U.S. wants. These include uranium, lithium, cobalt, rare earths and more and are used in applications such as batteries, technology and aerospace.

White House national security adviser Mike Waltz told the Conservative Political Action Conference on the outskirts of Washington on Friday: "Here's the bottom line, President Zelenskiy is going to sign that deal, and you will see that in the very short term."

'THEY DON'T HAVE ANY CARDS'

Speaking at a White House event earlier on Friday, Trump was critical of Zelenskiy while refraining from negative comments about Putin.

"I've had very good talks with Putin, and I've had not such good talks with Ukraine," Trump said. "They don't have any cards, but they're playing tough."

Separately, the United States on Friday proposed a United Nations resolution to mark the third anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The three-paragraph U.S. draft, seen by Reuters, mourns loss of life during the "Russia-Ukraine conflict" and "implores a swift end to the conflict."

Kyiv and its European allies want their own text to be adopted by the General Assembly on Monday calling for de-escalation, an early cessation of hostilities and peaceful resolution to the conflict.

The German government said on Friday that German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Zelenskiy agreed in a phone call that Ukraine must have a seat at the table in peace talks.

Polish President Andrzej Duda urged Zelenskiy, whose country borders Ukraine, on Friday to keep up calm and constructive cooperation with Trump, following the U.S. president's criticism of him.

Duda, whose term in office expires this year, was one of Trump's preferred international partners during his 2017-2021 presidency and they have described themselves as friends.

Poland's president is due to meet Trump in Washington on Saturday, Poland's state news agency PAP reported. (Reporting by Steve Holland, Nandita Bose, Trevor Hunnicutt and David Brunnstrom in Washington and Tom Balmforth in London; Editing by Ros Russell and Cynthia Osterman)

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as President of the United States and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly refers to "President Donald Trump" and quotes him directly. The name matches the target entity name and the description "President of the United States" is satisfied by the title used in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: Trump is quoted multiple times: "We're signing an agreement...", "I want to see a ceasefire...", and "They don't have any cards, but they're playing tough." These are clear statements attributed to him, confirming he is making declarations in the article.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q22686 (Donald Trump) is the only one whose profile lists the position "President of the United States" with a start date of 2025‑01‑20, matching the article’s context (Feb 21 2025). The other candidates (Trump Jr., a physician, and a son) do not hold the presidential office and are therefore irrelevant. Q22686 also matches the name and the political party affiliation, reinforcing the match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the office of President of the United States, giving him full authority to make the statements quoted in the article. The position is current (2025‑present) and the statements are made in the Oval Office, a typical venue for presidential remarks.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the sitting U.S. president to comment on Ukraine‑Russia negotiations, propose a UN resolution, and criticize Zelenskiy. The statements align with the president’s role in foreign policy and public communication.
reasoning.final_justification: All critical identification factors—name, title, current position, and context—align with candidate Q22686. The entity is present, making statements, and the candidate has the appropriate authority and plausibility for the attributed remarks. Therefore, Q22686 is the correct Wikidata ID.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as President of the United States and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Donald Trump as President of the United States and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

This matches the Wikidata entity’s name, title (President of Ukraine), and description. No other individual with a similar name is mentioned, and the context (Ukrainian politics, war, mineral agreement) aligns perfectly with the Wikidata profile.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Zelenskiy is quoted directly: "I am hoping for ... a fair result," and the article reports his statements about rejecting U.S. demands and his stance on the mineral agreement. These are clear attributions of speech to the identified entity.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for the President of Ukraine to comment on a proposed minerals agreement, express hopes for a fair result, and discuss negotiations with the United States. The statements are consistent with his role and the political context.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Zelenskiy and the Wikidata entity. The article’s references to him as president, his involvement in negotiations, and his statements all align with the Wikidata description.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Volodymyr Zelenskiy as the President of Ukraine and quotes him, confirming both the name and the exact description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Volodymyr Zelenskiy as the President of Ukraine and quotes him, confirming both the name and the exact description.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly names Mike Waltz and identifies him as the White House national security adviser, matching both the name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly names "White House national security adviser Mike Waltz" and quotes him speaking at the Conservative Political Action Conference. This confirms the target entity is present in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: Mike Waltz is directly quoted: "Here's the bottom line, President Zelenskiy is going to sign that deal, and you will see that in the very short term." This is a clear statement attributed to him.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q55386653 is Mike Waltz, listed as United States National Security Advisor with a start date of 2025‑01‑20 and an end date of 2025‑05‑01. The article date (Feb 21 2025) falls within this tenure, matching the description of a White House national security adviser. The second candidate (Q95813934) is an actor named Mike Waltze and does not fit the context or description. Therefore Q55386653 is the sole suitable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q55386653 holds the official position of National Security Advisor, giving him the authority to speak on U.S. policy matters such as the Ukraine minerals agreement. The statement is consistent with the responsibilities of that role.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the National Security Advisor to comment on a proposed deal with Ukraine at a political conference. The quote aligns with the expected public communications of that office.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity is present and making a statement. Candidate Q55386653 matches the name, role, and time frame, and has the appropriate authority and plausibility for the attributed quote. Thus the correct Wikidata ID is Q55386653.

reasoning.statement_detection: The text states that Duda "urged Zelenskiy" to keep calm and constructive cooperation, indicating a reported statement made by him. No direct quote is provided, but the verb "urged" clearly attributes a statement to him.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q9151911 is a Polish politician who served as President of the Republic of Poland from 2015 to 2025, matching the description "Polish President". All other candidates are unrelated professions (chemist, screenwriter, etc.). Thus Q9151911 is the sole viable match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q9151911 holds the office of President of Poland, giving him the authority to make public statements and diplomatic urges such as the one described.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for the Polish President to urge a neighboring country's leader to maintain calm and cooperation, especially in the context of regional security concerns highlighted in the article.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity is present, making a statement, and the only candidate that fits the description and context is Q9151911. Therefore, this Wikidata ID is the correct attribution.
